title: 111_hr3737
content: The Act titled "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" includes a Microloan Credit Building Initiative. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to require intermediaries to provide credit reporting information to major credit agencies for borrowers receiving loans under this subsection. Intermediaries can choose to provide credit reporting information to major credit agencies through the Administration or independently. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require individuals involved in making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act now requires individuals making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience in providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance. The Small Business Act now requires individuals making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience in providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing from $750,000 to $1,000,000 and from $3,500,000 to $7,000,000. The Administrator can treat the amount as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance by increasing the percentage from 25% to 35% in the Small Business Act. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program for providing technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing or operating small businesses. The Young Entrepreneurs Program provides assistance for establishing small businesses and securing financing for young entrepreneurs aged 25 and under. The Young Entrepreneurs Program defines a young entrepreneur as an individual aged 25 or younger who has lived in the intermediary's geographic area for at least 2 years. The Young Entrepreneurs Program defines a young entrepreneur as an individual aged 25 or younger who has lived in the intermediary's geographic area for at least 2 years. If a young entrepreneur establishes or operates a small business concern with assistance from an intermediary, they must make efforts to do so in the geographic area served by the intermediary. Additionally, a small business concern operated by a young entrepreneur may defer loan repayment for up to 6 months. A small business concern operated by a young entrepreneur may defer loan repayment for up to 6 months. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the loan size from $7,500 to $10,000. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the microloan program. The Administrator must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business detailing the names and locations of intermediaries receiving funds for microloans each fiscal year. The microloan program requires the Administrator to report on intermediaries receiving funds, including names, locations, loan and grant amounts, contributions from non-Federal sources, and details on microloans provided. The microloan program requires reporting on the number and amounts of microloans made by intermediaries to various groups, including women, low-income individuals, veterans, disabled individuals, and minorities. The microloan program requires intermediaries to report on the assistance provided to women, low-income individuals, veterans, disabled individuals, and minorities. The microloan program requires intermediaries to report on the assistance provided to veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs and business owners, including job creation, repayment history, and business success. The microloan program requires intermediaries to report on the repayment history and success of businesses that received assistance. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. Section 20 of the Small Business Act is amended to authorize the Administration to provide $80 million in technical assistance grants, $110 million in direct loans, and $10 million in interest assistance grants for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Authorization of appropriations is provided for technical assistance grants, direct loans, and interest assistance grants under section 7(m) of the Small Business Act. Such sums as necessary are authorized to be appropriated for this purpose. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
